Introduction

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a nonsuppurative complication of infection with nephritogenic strains of group A Streptococcus (GAS) (eg, Streptococcus pyogenes).  PSGN is the most common cause of nephritic syndrome in children.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



PSGN is an immune-complex mediated condition that occurs 7-10 days after GAS pharyngeal infection or 2-4 weeks after GAS skin infection (eg, impetigo, cellulitis).  During the initial infection, B cells produce IgG antibodies in response to nephritogenic antigens expressed by certain strains of GAS.  These antibodies form nephritogenic GAS antigen-antibody complexes that cause glomerular injury, as follows (

figure 1
):



  • Complement activation:  Immune complex deposition along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) activates the alternate complement pathway (ie, type III hypersensitivity reaction).  Complement component C3 accumulates within the immune complex deposits, leading to decreased serum C3 levels. 
  • Glomerular inflammation:  Complement activation induced an inflammatory response with leukocytic infiltration and cytokine production within the GBM.
  • Glomerular injury:  Neutrophil-mediated damage to glomerular podocytes leads to increased GBM permeability.  In addition, GBM thickening causes impaired glomerular filtration.


The primary risk factor for PSGN is infection with nephritogenic strains of GAS.  Therefore, PSGN is most common in school-aged children who are more likely to be exposed to streptococcal bacteria.  In addition, patients who are predisposed to secondary bacterial skin infection (eg, atopic dermatitis) are at increased risk.

Pathology



Histopathological examination of renal tissue in PSGN shows diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis characterized by the presence of inflammatory cells, including neutrophils and monocytes, within the glomeruli.



  • Light microscopy shows large, hypercellular glomeruli (
    image 1
    ).  Hypercellularity, which involves all lobules of all glomeruli, is the result of leukocyte infiltration and endothelial and mesangial cell proliferation in response to secreted cytokines.
  • Electron microscopy show immune complexes that appear as large, dome-shaped, subepithelial, electron-dense deposits ("humps") (
    image 2
    ). 
  • Immunofluorescence shows coarse, granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 that give the characteristic "lumpy-bumpy" GBM appearance (
    image 3
    ).

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation can vary from only microscopic hematuria to overt nephritic syndrome with the following symptoms:



  • Increased glomerular permeability:  Increased glomerular permeability typically results in hematuria (tea- or cola-colored) with or without red blood cell casts and mild proteinuria.  Urinary protein loss contributes to decreased intravascular oncotic pressure and third spacing. 
  • Impaired glomerular filtration:  Acute kidney injury (AKI) leads to impaired glomerular filtration (eg, increased serum creatinine) and sodium excretion. 


Combined water and sodium retention leads to volume overload with hypertension and edema (eg, generalized, periorbital).



Some patients present with a history of GAS infection; however, because the condition occurs 2-4 weeks after the primary infection, patients may not report a history of infection because they do not think it is relevant to their current condition.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of PSGN involves a thorough history and physical examination as well as laboratory tests.  The diagnosis is made in patients with signs and symptoms of acute nephritis (eg, hematuria, edema, hypertension) and either a history or laboratory evidence of recent GAS infection.  A renal biopsy is generally not necessary for diagnosis when the presentation is classic.  Standard laboratory evaluation in suspected PSGN includes:



  • Urinalysis:  Urinalysis detects hematuria with or without red blood cell casts and variable degrees of proteinuria.
  • Complement:  Complement components C3 and CH50 (marker of total complement activity) levels are markedly decreased in the first two weeks of illness.  C4 (marker of classical pathway activation) levels are typically normal but may be low in patients with activation of both complement pathways.  Low serum C3 and normal serum C4 levels are a distinguishing feature of PSGN.  C3 and CH50 levels normalize within 4-8 weeks.
  • Renal function:  Serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels are often elevated due to glomerular injury and impaired glomerular filtration. 
  • Streptozyme test:  The streptozyme test measures 5 different streptococcal antibodies, including anti-streptolysin, anti-hyaluronidase, anti-streptokinase, anti-nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotidase, and anti-DNase B antibodies.  Various combinations of these titers will be elevated depending on the type of precedent streptococcal infection.  Because PSGN presents weeks after the initial streptococcal infection, throat and/or skin cultures may be negative. 

Differential diagnosis



Differential diagnosis of PSGN includes other causes of glomerulonephritis such as IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis, and IgA vasculitis.  Distinguishing features include clinical and laboratory findings.  Renal biopsy may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis in some cases.



  • IgA nephropathy (

    ):  occurs days (not weeks) after an upper respiratory tract infection.  Pathogenic IgA antibodies are produced in response to mucosal infection and form deposits in the mesangium, causing glomerular inflammation and injury.  Patients may be asymptomatic or present with hematuria with or without flank pain, low-grade fever, and hypertension.  Unlike PSGN, patients with IgA nephropathy have normal C3, CH50, and C4 levels.  Also, IgA nephropathy often recurs with subsequent upper respiratory tract infections whereas recurrence is rare in PSGN.
  • Lupus nephritis and IgA vasculitis (also known as Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein Purpura nephritis):  Unlike patients with PSGN, patients with lupus nephritis and IgA vasculitis have extrarenal manifestations of these disease (eg, arthritis/arthralgia, rash).  Complement levels may also distinguish these diagnoses; patients with lupus nephritis have low C3 and C4 levels, and patients with IgA vasculitis have normal complement levels. 

Management



Management of PSGN focuses on supportive care and treatment of complications due to volume overload, including hypertension and pulmonary edema.  First-line treatment for hypertension and edema is loop diuretics (eg, furosemide).  Most patients do not require adjunctive therapy, but additional antihypertensives (eg, calcium channel blockers) should be given to those with hypertensive encephalopathy (eg, headache) or hypertension refractory to diuresis.  Fluid restriction may be indicated, and caution should be used with intravenous fluids because they may worsen edema and hypertension.  Antibiotics may be indicated to treat ongoing streptococcal infection.  In severe cases with rapidly declining renal function, dialysis may be considered.

Prognosis



The prognosis of PSGN is generally favorable, particularly in children.  The majority of pediatric patients with PSGN, even those with acute kidney injury and nephritic syndrome, have complete clinical recovery within weeks, although urinalysis findings may take months to normalize.



However, as many as 40% of adults diagnosed with PSGN develop chronic kidney disease, persistent hypertension, or recurrent proteinuria, with 10% progressing to end-stage renal disease.  Preexisting kidney disease, metabolic syndrome, and diabetes are also poor prognostic indicators.

Summary



Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) (

) is a nonsuppurative complication of infection with nephritogenic strains of group A beta-hemolytic Streptococcus species (eg, pharyngitis, impetigo) that occurs due to immune complex deposition on the glomerular basement membrane.  Patients typically present with hematuria, proteinuria (variable), edema, hypertension, and oliguria with low C3 and CH50 levels.  Diagnosis requires history or laboratory evidence of recent streptococcal infection.  Treatment is supportive, although patients may require loop diuretics and restricted salt/water intake due to complications of volume overload (eg, hypertension, pulmonary edema).
